content.description:
It's basically a face route with imaginary holds. 
 Be careful of big block near the anchor, it moves but wont come out, so don't place pro around it or leave your hand under it if you grab the top!

Third line of bolts on the left face of the needle.
MIXED, 4 bolts & a couple small-medium pieces.

The second line of bolt going up the left face of the spire. mixed, 4 bolts
bolted belay/rap

From the left end of the ledge, make an exposed clip. Scarier the shorter you are. Delicate climbing past first bolt then to better holds.

Three bolts plus some finger size cams for the top helps

climbs.name: Face Ouest
climbs.fa: Normand Cadieux, Edouard Pierre Gagnon, summer 1977

content.description:
Start on the midway ledge, going up the cave on the outer left corner of the Needle. Exit the cave by the right side and move up a flake. Once you feet clear the roof, traverse left and to a beautiful fingercrack to the top. Small to medium rack.
Belay/rap anchor on top, need a 60m+ rope to rap.

Climb Face ouest or Lavallee Directe and exit the roof to the flake. 
 Once you get to the flake, don't head left to the vertical crack but head straight up the face.

small rack, 1 bolt, bolted belay/rap anchor.

Welcome to chimney-offwidths, The start is a bit exposed but you'll find some gear on the right face before you hit the roof and corner exit. the right corner on the needle's south/right face. Standard rack.
Bolted anchor

Starting from the ledge easily accessed from the "Cheminée" route, go staight up to a large horizontal crack, move left of the arete, then back up to the summit.

Careful, beginning of the climb is on a slab where the only protection easily installed will be a "00 Mastercam". It's a bit far to reach even for someone tall and the previous pro will be far from you. From the horizontal crack, protection is correct and easy, but bring long slings to reduce the drag from zigzagging to left and back to the summit.

Start by climbing up the obvious "Cheminée" route left of Fatman's Misery. The route starts from the ledge, where 2 bolted anchors are located.
On the top are bolted anchors and chain allowing to rap down on either side of the "Aiguille" or to set up top ropes.

Voie d'accès pour les longueurs de l'Aiguille. Très facile mais tout de même intéressant. Sortir à gauche au bout de la cheminée. 

Access route to get to routes going to the top of l'Aiguille. Very easy but entertaining nonetheless. Exit to your left at the end of the chimney. 



Côté sud de l'Aiguille, à la base. 

South side of l'Aiguille, at the base. 


#0.3 à #3. J'ai utilisé le #0.3, #3, #0.4 et #0.5. Attention au drag!

#0.3 to #3. I used #0.3, #3, #0.4 and #0.5. Watch for drag!

This route is a direct start variation to Face Ouest. Instead of starting on the intermediate ledge on the left of the needle it starts from the base of the needle (south?). Delicate moves passed 2 bolts on small holds to reach the regular Face Ouest under the roof. starts on the left side of the bottom of the needle (facing the trail/road) 2 bolts + double finger sized rack + single 1-2"
bolted top belay/rap.

Start off on Ochra, Face Ouest or Lavallee Directe. From Ochra, climb the right face of the arete to the top. From Face Ouest, keep traversing left passed the vertical crack above the roof and head up the face on the right of the arete. small rack, 3 bolts (some shared with Ochra)
Bolted belay/rap.

From the corner, make your way up to the roomy ledge, now get your affairs in order and quickly move up onto the needle protecting high and having a tight belay, a fall on the ledge may cause some damage.
Commit to the roof and a small vertical flake jammed in the crack and traverse up and right bear-hugging a large block. keep moving up the slab until you reach the gap with the massive flake blocking the way, you can traverse the crevasse underneath the block or climb up and over it to the glue-in anchor.

From inside the open chamber on the right of l'Aiguille, find the corner which has an opening underneath with some nasty flakes.
Single rack to 3", 4" possible before the roof.

Getting off the ground is the crux! Play around with the first horizontal until you can figure out a way to hold on to the next horrible hold solidly. Go up to the ledge, straight up a little dihedral pass a roof by the left and keep running up this easier ground to the top. Base of the needle, overhanging start onto a horizontal crack. Someone was nice enough to retro-bolt the bottom section.
small to medium trad pro.
Stick clip highly recommended.

A lot of very balancy moves, and a few ways to get it done.

Right arrête of the left face of the Needle.
MIXED 5 bolts, couple small to medium pieces on top, Bolted anchor.

Start by stemming between the east face of the needle and the other faces then continue climbing the east/north face corner and exit to the north face after the third bolt joining Face Nord or Bisbille. 
  
 Variation: 
 start up the corner without stemming 5.12c.

small rack, 3 bolts.

The free standing chunk of rock away from the cliff.
Once someone leads one of the easier routes (like Face Ouest), it's possible to set up top ropes along the north face (Super Dupont to Belzebuth) and along the west face (Bidouble to Face Ouest Direct).
Ochra and Face Ouest will need directionals with potential for some scary swings.
There's also the possibility of setting up a tyrolean accross the main cliff and the needle, of course, take all associated precautions and that hook should not be considered life bearing.

Le morceau de rocher qui se détache de la falaise.
Une fois que quelqu'un lead l'une des voies les plus faciles (comme Face ouest), il est possible d'installer des moulinettes le long de la face nord (Super Dupont à Belzebuth) et le long de la face ouest (Bidouble à Face ouest directe).
Ochra et Face ouest auront besoin de directionnelles avec un potentiel de balants effrayants.
Il y a aussi la possibilité d'installer une tyrolienne en travers de la falaise principale et l'aiguille, bien sûr, prendre toutes les précautions associées et ce crochet ne doit pas être considéré comme porteur de vie.
